titleStmt.title: M108 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 7p. Paginated 23-28, with an unpaginated page at end.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M108 [The Reader]. Typescript fragment, with the author's ms. corrections, unsigned and undated. 7p. Paginated 23-28, with an unpaginated page at end.

These and successive folders of [The Reader] were contained in two multigrip folders, headed by Virginia Woolf: "Turning the page"; "Transformations" and "Spare sheets of T.P." labels on the spines. They are filed under her Anon, holograph and typescript fragments.

The fragments grouped in the successive folders under [The reader] may or may not have formed part of Anon. They have been grouped in this fashion based on the evidence of paper and typewriters. The pagination 23-28 is the lowest in the sequence. Internal evidence would indicate that manuscript drafts preceded that of Anon, since Articles, 1938-9 notebook contains a fragment. Some of the versos of this run of material contains fragments of typescripts of Between the Acts and other contemporary works.

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in / tags, wrapped in a element.

normalization.p: Where appropriate, spelling and punctuation have been modernised using / tags, wrapped in a element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

p.l: There us a jolt at the points. Lovely as the words are,
the mind slides on to a another rail. To speak them the poet

has separated t himself from the
actirs actors . He cannot yet make
Tamburlaine speak those words with his own lips. The play

is still in part the work of the
undiffrenetiated undifferentiated audience,
demanding great names, great deeds, simple outlines,
and not the single subtlety of one soul.

and Lord Rutland, as Roland
W ite Whyte wrote to Sir Robert

l.quote: "pass away their time in London, merely in going to

p.l: plays every day" But the attraction, strong as it was,

that drew them to the
Banside Bankside , roused no comment. A young

poet
dedictes dedicates his sonnets to Mr W H. and not one of those
highly educated nobles troubles to ask Who is this patron?

It is not a matter of
i nterest interest
i in court circles.
If we try to look at the audience off the stage
in their private lives we see only wisps, passing phantoms.
